Enhanced catalytic transfer hydrogenation of biomass-based furfural into furfuryl alcohol over Co3O4-based mixed oxide catalysts from hydrotalcite Shifang Cheng Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation a Junfang Ding Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis c Yakai Chen Investigation a Ganen Pan Investigation a Xinya Feng Investigation a Xingliang Xu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ Jing Xu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a b ⁎⁎ a College of Chemistry and Material Science, Shandong Agricultural University, Taian, Shandong, China College of Chemistry and Material Science, Shandong Agricultural University Taian Shandong China College of Chemistry and Material Science, Shandong Agricultural University, Taian, Shandong, China. b Key Laboratory of Agricultural Film Application of Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Taian, Shandong, China Key Laboratory of Agricultural Film Application of Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs Taian Shandong China Key Laboratory of Agricultural Film Application of Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Taian, Shandong, China. c College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University Hohhot China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot, China. ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Chemistry and Material Science, Shandong Agricultural University, Taian, Shandong, China. College of Chemistry and Material Science, Shandong Agricultural University Taian Shandong China Catalytic furfural (FF) into high value-added furfuryl alcohol (FOL) is a very important biomass improvement process and remains a challenging task. Herein, a series of Co-based composite oxide (CoMgAl-LDO) catalysts with highly dispersed Co3O4-based spinel oxide nanoparticles were synthesized by the topological transformation of Co-based ternary layered hydroxides (CoMgAl-LDH) under calcination conditions and tested for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL using isopropanol (2-PrOH) as hydrogen donor. The CoMgAl-LDO, especially Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO calcinated at 500 °C (Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500) offered the outstanding catalytic performance for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL (99.7 % FF conversion and 95.9 % FOL selectivity), which was attributed to effectively dispersed active sites, abundant acid-base sites and mesoporous structure. Additionally, the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst manifested good stability with wider universality to other carbonyl compounds, making the catalytic system extremely economical and practical in various biomass hydrogenation processes. Graphical Abstract Co3O4-based mixed oxide catalysts from hydrotalcite for the transfer hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol. Keywords Furfural Transfer hydrogenation Furfuryl alcohol Hydrotalcite Co3O4 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the rapid depletion of fossil resources, the development of reliable renewable energy sources has received widespread attention in the energy and chemical fields [1,2]. Therein, biomass is used as the only organic carbon source for the efficient production of high value-added liquid fuels and chemicals in various chemical reactions [3,4]. Among biomass-derived compounds, furfural (FF) is a typical biomass-based furan compound, which can be easily produced through the acid hydrolysis of agricultural waste biomass [5]. FF has a high oxygen content and a variety of unsaturated functional groups and can be further transformed to a variety of useful chemicals through the selective hydrogenation [6]. Focusing on hydrogenation processes, around 62 % of FF is converted to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) through the selective reduction of the CO bond due to its wide range of industrial application value [7]. Traditional hydrogenation of FF to FOL was implemented with the existence of high- pressure H2 using copper chromite (CuCr2O4) as catalyst, which implies there are safety risks and environmental issues [8]. In addition, the CC bond of FF is often preferentially reduced rather than the CO bond using H2 as a hydrogen source under the action of metal catalysts, resulting in a decrease in the selectivity of FOL [9–11]. In this context, it is highly necessary to find an efficient and environmentally friendly catalytic systems for the selective hydrogenation of the CO bond in FF to FOL. In recent years, catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) has become an attractive method for the hydrogenation of biomass-based oxygenated compounds due to its ability to avoid the use of high-pressure hydrogen and provide mild reaction conditions [12–14]. Heterogeneous metal-based catalyst can effectively activate the CO bond of FF through the metal-hydride-mediated reaction pathway [15]. Although some metal based catalysts have high hydrogenation activity, they usually adsorb FF by the model of η2(C,O) and can lead to side reactions such as decarboxylation, cyclohydrogenation, and C-C bond breakage, resulting in the poor selectivity for furfural alcohol [16,17]. In contrast, solid acid-base catalysts, especially some metal oxides, can promote the hydrogen transfer reaction between alcohols and carbonyls through a direct hydrogen transfer mechanism, known as Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) mechanism, to achieve the selective reduction of the CO bond of FF [18–20]. However, metal oxides have a very stable coordination with oxygen compared with other types of catalysts, which makes them inert and difficult to adsorb substrates and hydrogen donors, resulting in weaker catalytic performance [21]. Previous reports have shown that heterogeneous Co-based catalysts, in particular, cobalt oxide (Co3O4) have been developed for the transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds due to their excellent redox and acid-base properties [22,23]. Nonetheless, many of Co3O4 based catalytic systems present one or more of the following problems such as complicated catalyst preparations and use of toxic organic ligands, leaching and agglomerating of catalytic active component [24,25]. In lieu of these limitations, the development of high activity, high selectivity, and sustainable Co3O4 based catalysts for the selective catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL is highly desirable. Hydrotalcite (LDH) is a layered hydroxide consisting of a positively charged matrix layer with metal hydroxides and exchangeable interlayer regions, which can be topological transformed to a series of transition metal composite oxide (LDO) materials by manipulating the types and proportions of elements between layers [26,27]. Compared with LDH, LDO materials show many advantages for heterogeneous catalytic reactions, such as high thermal stability, large surface area and porosity, small metal domains and good metal oxide dispersion [28]. For example, Co-based ternary LDH (CoMgAl-LDH) have Co(OH)6 units in the two-dimensional layered structure, which are appropriate precursors for the preparation of Co3O4-based spinel oxide phases catalysts by the calcination treatment [29,30]. More importantly, during heat treatment-induced phase transitions, metal ions (Mg2+ and Al3+ ions) change from order to disorder and form an open amorphous mesoporous structure, which can effectively stabilize and disperse active Co3O4 species and have high interaction in the Co-based composite oxide (LDO) materials [31]. Besides, the composite metal oxides obtained by calcination of hydrotalcite precursors have excellent acid-base properties, which can promote the formation of hydrogen substances and the selective adsorption of the CO bond in the transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds [32]. Consequently, in this work, we aimed to create Co3O4-based composite oxide (LDO) materials by the calcination treatment of CoMgAl-LDH precursors that would be selective towards hydrogenation of the CO bond of FF in the transfer hydrogenation. In this work, we successfully prepared a series of CoMgAl-LDH precursors with different molar ratios using the co-precipitation method, and then obtained ternary composite metal oxides (CoMgAl-LDO) at various calcined temperatures between 300 and 700 °C. XRD analysis results indicated that CoMgAl-LDH precursors were topological transformed to nanoscale Co3O4 spinel phases with Mg-Al oxide amorphous phase at 500 °C, and further thermal treatment led to the increase of the spinel phases particle size. The obtained Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 (Calcination temperature was 500 ℃) exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the selective catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL under optimal conditions ( 99.7 % conversion; 95.9 % selectivity), which is attributed to the excellent dispersion of Co3O4, abundant acid-base sites, and large specific surface area. In addition, the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 ℃ showed excellent cyclic stability and substrate universality. Finally, a reasonable reaction mechanism was proposed combined with performance testing and structural characterization. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR≥98 %), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, AR≥98 %), aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3•9H2O, AR≥98 %), and magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2•6H2O, AR≥98 %) were purchased from Tianjin chemical reagent factory. Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2•6H2O, AR≥98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, isopropanol, and 2-butanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. FF (C5H4O2, AR≥98 %) and FOL (C5H6O2, AR≥98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Analytic-grade (AR) reactants can be used directly in all experiments without further processing. 2.2 Preparation of CoMgAl-LDO CoxMg3-xAl1-LDH precursor (x= 0, 1, 1.5, 2 and 3) was prepared by the low-sudesaturation coprecipitation method. A typical sample of Co1Mg1.5Al1-LDH was prepared as follows: firstly, 50 mL of 0.166 mol·L−1 Na2CO3 solution in a 500 mL three-necked round-bottomed flask and 100 mL of 1 mol·L−1 NaOH solution were prepared, while the metallic nitrates of Co(NO3)2•6H2O (0.015 mol), Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.015 mol), and Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (0.01 mol) were separately dissolved in deionized water (50 mL) to configure a nitrate mixture with Co: Mg: Al= 1.5:1.5:1. Then the metallic nitrate solution and NaOH solution were dropwise added simultaneously into the flask under stirring (1000 rpm) until the pH kept 9–11 at 60 ℃ for 3 h. Next, the turbid liquid was cooled to room temperature, and filtered. The solids collected above were dissolved in 30.00 mL of 2 mol·L−1 Na2CO3 solution under stirring (1000 rpm) at 40 ℃ for 12 h. The turbid liquid was vacuumized and washed with deionized water, and dried at 60 ℃. The resulting LDH precursor was respectively further calcined in a muffle furnace at a temperature gradient of 300 ℃, 500 ℃, and 700 ℃ for 120 min with a heating ramp rate of 5 ℃·min−1, and denoted as Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-T (T = 300, 500, and 700). The molar ratio of elements in different compound oxides is basically consistent with the feeding ratio (Table S1). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The content of Co, Mg, and Al were measured by an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) with an Agilent 720ES (OES), and the presence of Co, Mg, and Al, along with the chemical composition, were determined by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (Sigma 300). Using a Cu Kα target (λ = 0.154 nm), the X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) of the sample was obtained in the range of 2θ = 5°-80° with Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer. The FT-IR spectra were characterized in the detection range of 400–4000 cm−1 by the Bruker Vector 22. Scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) (Sigma 300) at 20 kV, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (FEI, Tecnai F20) at 200 kV recorded the morphology and particle distribution of the catalyst, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were performed using the US Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer, which was tested with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) as the X-ray source, and the peak charge was calibrated using C 1 s (284.6 eV). The BET specific surface area and pore structure were determined was obtained by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method using the automatic specific surface area analyzer of Micromeritics APSP 2460 model and the nitrogen adsorption and desorption test of the sample under the condition of N2. Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to study the thermal decomposition temperature of the sample and the weight loss ratio of the sample using the TA Q600, in which the sample was heated up to 800 ℃ from 25 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃·min−1 in an air atmosphere. The composition of acid sites in cobalt-base composite oxide samples was determined by pyridine adsorption Fourier-transform infrared (Py-IR) (Tensor 27). The technology platform development (TPD) of NH3 and CO2 (NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD) analyzed the strength and distribution of acid and base sites in catalysts, which was performed on an AUTO CHEM 2920 in the range of 50 ℃ to 600 ℃ at a heating rise rating of 10 ℃·min−1 in He atmosphere, and the removed gas (NH3 or CO2) was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4 Catalytic performance investigation Catalytic transfer hydrogenation is carried out in a stirred Teflon reactor with self-lifting pressure. In this process, 1.2 mmol furfural, 20 mL 2-PrOH and 0.1 g of catalyst were added to the reactor, sealed, and placed in the heating module of a high-temperature kettle and heated to the target temperature (120–200 ℃). Subsequently, the reactor kept stirring at the selected temperature (500 rpm) and reacted for a certain reaction time (2–10 h). Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and opened to process the sample after the reaction. A scaled-up experimental investigation of catalytic transfer hydrogenation was carried out using a 300 mL stainless steel autoclave. In this scaled-up setup, the autoclave was loaded with FF (12 mmol), 2-PrOH (200 mL), and a catalyst (1 g). Subsequently, the autoclave was sealed and subjected to heating at 160 ℃ for 6 h. The FF and FOL were analyzed by GC-MS (Fig. S10). The heating procedure was that the column temperature was kept at 60 ℃ for 4 min and then increased to 220 ℃ at a temperature rate of 20 ℃·min−1.and kept for 10 min. Unsaturated aldehydes and corresponding alcohols were qualitatively analyzed by mass spectrometry (Supporting Information). The calculation formulas for FF conversion (mol%), FOL yield (mol%), and selectivity (mol%) are as follows: Con = M i − M f M i × 100 % M i : the molar of FF before the reaction M f : the molar of FF after the reaction Sel = Q f M i − M f × 100 % Q f : the molar of FOL after the reaction Yie = Q f M i × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the materials The crystal structure of the prepared samples was investigated by the powder X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD). Fig. S1 and Fig. 1a show the XRD patterns of the LDH precursors. All CoxMg3-xAl1-LDH precursors (x=0, 1, 1.5, 2 and 3) exhibit three high-strength peaks at 11.5°, 23.3°and 34.5°, corresponding to (003), (006) and (012) planes respectively for the typical 2D LDH, indicating the crystal structure of LDH was not damaged by the introduction of Co [33,34]. The diffraction peak attributed to (110) and (113) crystal plane appears at 60.4° and 61.6°, respectively, suggesting a good dispersion of metallic anions in brucite-like layers [35]. It is worthwhile mentioning that the intensity of characteristic diffraction peak of LDH gradually weakens with the increase of cobalt content (Fig. S1). This is probably because the ionic radius of Co is larger than that of Mg [36]. The above results indicate that cobalt based ternary LDH was successfully prepared. To study the thermal stability of CoMgAl-LDH precursors and determine the appropriate calcination temperature, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH was carried out under an air atmosphere (Fig. S2). The TGA of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH reveals three obvious mass losses in the range of 25–800℃. The first mass loss occurred at 25–200 °C accounting for 11.96 % total mass loss, corresponding to the removal of adsorbed and interlayer water [37]. The second mass loss occurring at 200–450 °C accounted for 22.59 % of total mass loss, which results from the thermal decomposition of hydroxylation and carbonate anions in the interlayer of hydrotalcite [38]. A third and final mass loss at 450–800℃ with 3.05 % mass loss, which is attributed to the transformation of the mixed metal oxides into a spinel phase [38]. Taking Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH as the column, we studied the influence of calcination temperature on the structure of LDH. It is obvious from Fig. 1b that, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the precursor of LDH basically disappear with the increase of calcination temperature (300–700 0C), and new diffraction peaks appear and the intensity gradually increases. It can be found that Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 shows broad peaks at 36.8°, 44.8° and 65.2°, which are unique to cobalt-based spinel phase (Co3O4, Co2AlO4 and CoAl2O4) with lower intensity [39]. It is difficult to determine the differences in cobalt-based spinel structure from XRD data, which is attributed to their very similar structures. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks of Al2O3 and MgO were not detected in the calcination process, suggesting that Al2O3 and MgO are amorphous oxide or the Al and Mg are transferred to into Co3O4 lattice form cobalt-based spinel structure during the calcination processes [40]. Considering that the Co/Al ratio is 1.5/1, it can be inferred that the Co3O4 phase is the dominant phase in Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500, similar to the previously reported [36]. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peak of Co3O4 become more obvious at 700 ℃, which confirms the growth of Co3O4 in the calcined samples. The particle size of pristine Co3O4 is about 18.7 nm calculated by Scherrer equation (D=Kλ/βcosθ) applied for (311), quite larger than that of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 (8.3 nm). The XRD results reveal that the CoMgAl-LDH precursors were topological transformed to a complex of Co3O4 and magnesium aluminum oxide amorphous phases. The transformation of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO during calcination was verified by FT-IR analysis. As shown in Fig. 2, two peaks at 3460 cm−1 and 1600 cm−1 could be ascribed to the hydroxyl stretching vibration mode of hydroxyl groups and the bending vibration mode of hydroxyl groups, showing the presence of H2O and OH- on Co-based ternary LDH [41]. A strong peak at 1360 cm−1 could be assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode and out of plane deformation vibration of interlayer carbonate material [42]. In addition, the M-O stretching vibration at 615 cm−1 and 562 cm−1 [43]. With the increase of calcination temperature, the characteristic peaks of hydroxyl and carbonate gradually weaken, while the peaks of metal oxides gradually increase [44]. The above results show again that the structure of LDH was destroyed and metal oxides were formed after calcinations at higher temperatures. The morphological features of the samples were analyzed by SEM and TEM. Fig. S3 shows SEM images of the prepared Mg3Al1-LDH, Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO at different calcination temperatures (300–700 0C). The prepared Mg3Al1-LDH (Fig. S3a) and Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (Fig. S3b and Fig. 3a) present the similar lamellar structure, which indicates that the introduction of cobalt does not change the structure of hydrotalcite. Additionally, when the calcination temperature is between 300 and 500 0C, the lamellar structure basically remains unchanged (Fig. S3c-d and Fig. 3b)，but the calcination temperature continued to increase, and the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-700 appears sintering phenomenon and tend to agglomerate (Fig. S3e). This belongs to the elimination of carbonate ions and water molecules in the interlaminar region and the dehydroxylation process in the high temperature calcination. As shown in Fig. 3c, the TEM images show that Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 have overall particle sizes and retain the lamellar morphology. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 (Fig. 3d) shows the distinct lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.29 nm, which match well respectively with the (220) planes of the road shaped Co3O4, as consistent with XRD results [31]. The lattice fringe of crystal phase corresponding to Al2O3 and MgO were not observed, confirming that the Al and Mg-related phase is the non-crystalline state or most of Al and Mg species entered Co3O4 spinel lattice to form cobalt-based spinel structure. The detailed elemental distribution for the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 was analyzed by the corresponding elemental mapping shown in Fig. 3e-h, which exhibits a homogeneous distribution of Co, Mg, Al, and O elements throughout the whole sample. The EDS analysis shows that the molar ratio of Co: Mg: Al in the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 is 1.13:1.12:0.72 (Fig. 3i), which is basically consistent with the initial feeding ratio (nCo: nMg: nAl=1.5:1.5:1) and the results of ICP (displayed in Table S1). Therefore, the above analysis results confirms that Co3O4 nanoparticles have been formed and bound to ternary composite metal oxides (Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500) under calcined conditions. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 are shown in Fig. S4. Both the samples display a type-IV isotherm curves with an H3-type hysteresis loop, implying existence of mesoporous structure. The results of N2 sorption reveal that the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 possesses a much larger specific surface area (152.46 m2/g) than their LDH precursors (102.23 m2/g) due to the removal of the interlayer anion groups under calcined conditions (Table S2), which would provide more exposed active sites and promote the mass transfer. Although, compared with Mg3Al1-LDO-500 (199.97 m2/g), the specific surface area of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 is decreased, which indicates that the catalytic performance is not only related to the specific surface area, but also to the cobalt species. To further compare the influence of the change of chemical elements in the sample on the catalytic performance before and after calcination, XPS analysis was performed for the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH and Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500. It can be seen from the full patterns of XPS (Fig. S5) that the existence of Co, Mg, Al and O elements in the sample before and after calcination, being consistent with the results of EDS. From Fig. 4a, the Co 2p XPS patterns exhibits two contributions, 2p 1/2 and 2p 3/2. The coexistence of Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 in Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH catalyst is evidenced by a shoulder observed on the main peak at 781.8 eV and 797.7 eV, which is assigned to Co2+ species [45]. Notably, two satellite peaks of cobalt species at 786.5 eV and 803.5 eV were associated with the oxidation of cobalt [46]. Upon high-temperature calcination, Co 2p spectrum of the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO presents two distinct peaks at 779.7 (2p1/2) and 794.9 eV (2p3/2) with a distance of about 15.2 eV and has a pair of weak satellite doublet peaks, and the characteristic peaks at 779.7 and 794.9 eV are associated with Co3+ species. conforming to the typical mixed valence state of Co3O4, which are in good agreement with the previously reported values [47]. The signal peaks at 780.8 and 796.6 eV are attributed to the characteristic peaks of Co2+ species [48]. In addition, two weak satellite peaks of Co3O4 at about 788.6 and 804.0 eV are originating from the unpaired electrons existed in Co2+ valence orbital [49]. The concentration of surface Co3+ in the samples is calculated based on the area of XPS fitting results (Table S3). As listed in Table S3, one can see that the surface content of Co3+ increased with the increase of calcination temperature. It is well known that the enhanced Lewis acidity of Co3+ over Co2+ is conducive to the selective activation of CO bonds [50]. In addition, Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 was found to have relatively low amount of Co3+on its surface compared with single Co3O4 sample (calcining at 500 ℃, Fig. S6a and Table S3), indicating that the oxide obtained through calcination of hydrotalcite precursor has certain defect sites. To further identify the oxygen species in the samples, O 1 s spectra were processed by peak splitting. As shown in Fig. 4b, O 1 s can be divided into two characteristic peaks. The 530–529 eV is attributed to the lattice oxygen (Olatt) and the 531–532 eV is attributed to the surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively.[51]. For Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH, the oxygen species are mainly Oads and belong to the surface hydroxyl group (O-H). Meanwhile, the intensity and proportion of Olatt at 529.6 eV increased gradually with the higher calcination temperature, which thanks to the removal of -OH helped M and O capture each other of electrons to form M-O bonds. This phenomenon is consistent with FTIR results. Oads could be activated easily and usually considered as the main adsorption site, promoting the formation of hydrogen protons in the catalytic activity of transfer hydrogenation [21]. However, excessive adsorption sites are not conducive to the desorption of products and increase the possibility of side reactions. It can be clearly seen that Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 has moderate Olatt (Co-O-M/Co-O-Co) and appropriate Oads compared with other samples (Table S4), which can provide abundant basic sites in the hydrogen transfer reaction, thus promoting the formation of hydrogen protons [52]. When compared with single Co3O4 sample (Table S4 and Fig. S6a), Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 with hierarchical interfaces possess a relatively high content of Oads/(Oads+Olatt). In other words, Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 with nanoscale Co3O4 could promote the formation of more surface oxygen defects and expose more easily activated oxygen (Oads). These results suggest that Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 with highly dispersed and small sized Co3O4 phase can produce suitable adsorption site affording the subsequent catalytic transfer hydrogenation. The formation of acid-base sites in metal oxides catalysts can be attributed to acidic (M+) and basic (O2-) species, which dominantly responsible for the CTH reaction through direct hydrogenation transfer. To further confirm the effect of cobalt species on acid-base properties of ternary composite metal oxides (CoMgAl-LDO), the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD spectra of Mg3Al1-LDO-500 and Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 were investigated ( Fig. 5a-b). As shown in Fig. 5a, all LDO samples contain weakly and moderately acidic sites, corresponding to the NH3-TPD profiles in temperature range of 50 °C-300 °C and 300 °C-500 °C, respectively. Weak and medium acids should be related to the remaining aluminum hydroxide(M-OH) and oxides (Mg-O-Al and Co-O-Al), respectively [53]. Although, the normalized surface density of weak and medium acidic sites of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 are lower than that of Mg3Al1-LDO-500 (Table S5), Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 has a strong acid absorption peak above 500 °C compared with Mg3Al1-LDO-500, which correspond to coordinatively unsaturated cobalt ions [53]. Previous studies have shown that coordinatively unsaturated metals sites can be used as Lewis acid sites with the ability to activate CO in catalytic transfer hydrogenation [17]. As observed in the CO2-TPD profiles, it is obvious that the CO2-TPD signal strength of Mg3Al1-LDO-500 is significantly lower than that of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500, which may be due to the interaction of MgO and Al2O3. The CO2-TPD profiles of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 can be divided into three different temperature ranges, corresponding to weak base (50 °C-300 °C), medium base (300 °C-500 °C) and strong base sites (above 500 °C) [54]. It is interesting that Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 indicates an obviously increased intensity of the CO2 desorption peak in the high-temperature region (300–500°C and 500–600 °C), which suggests its increase in medium and strong base sites. The normalized surface density of base sites on Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 was 0.76 mmol/g, much higher than that of Mg3Al1-LDO-500 (Table S6), which may be attributed to the Co cations replacing Mg in mixed oxides. In this case, defects are generated on the surface of the oxide to compensate for the generated positive charge, resulting in unsaturated coordination of adjacent oxygen anions [55]. To better clarify the composition of acidic sites in cobalt based composite oxide samples, the FTIR spectra of the pyridine adsorption (Pyridine-IR) spectra were measured (Fig. 5c). Typically, the peaks at 1610 and 1450 cm−1 are attributed to the Lewis acid centers, while pyridine adsorbed on the Brønsted acid centers is observed at 1560 cm−1. A band at 1490 cm−1 represents both the Brønsted acid centers and the Lewis acid centers [56]. More importantly, it is clear from Fig. 5d that the introduction of cobalt species can provide abundant Lewis acid sites, which are attributed to the highly dispersed Co3O4 species. As reported by numerous authors, Lewis acid sites were conducive to the adsorption and activation of the CO bond in FF [10,12]. Combing the above characterization results, the introduction of Co3O4 could optimize the concentration of basic and acid sites on the mixed oxide catalyst surface, and improve the catalytic transfer hydrogenation activity. 3.2 Investigation of catalytic performance The catalytic performance of various catalyst was tested for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation by selecting the hydrogenation of FF as the probe reaction with 2-PrOH as both solvent and H-donor. During the initial catalytic test, we evaluated the catalytic performance of all samples at 160 ℃ for a duration of 6 h, and the obtained results are presented in Table 1. No reaction occurred without catalyst in the controlled blank experiment (Table 1, Entry 1). Compared with Mg3Al1-LDH (Table 1, Entry 2), the conversion of FF increased to 53.5 % and the FOL selectivity increased to 79.6 % over Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDH (Table 1, Entry 3) with the introduction of cobalt, which was attributed to the fact that cobalt species can act as a Lewis acid to activate the CO bond. More obviously, all the composite oxides (CoMgAl-LDO) obtained from calcined LDH precursors significantly enhance the catalytic performance of the catalysts, while also increasing the selectivity towards FOL (Table 1, Entry 4–10), mainly because compared to LDH, LDO exhibits excellent porous structure and acid-base performance, which is conducive to catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions [32]. The highest FOL selectivity of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 was 95.9 % with a 99.7 % conversion of FF. Although Mg3Al1-LDO-500 and Co1Mg2Al1-LDO-500 showed high furfural conversion (>99 %), we detected some of the aldol condensation byproducts, resulting in a significant decrease in the selectivity of FOL, which was attributed to the higher content of magnesium, which increased the alkalinity of the catalyst and thus promoted the aldol condensation reaction. Moreover, the catalytic performance of Co3Al1-LDO-500 and Co2Mg1Al1-LDO-500 catalysts with higher Co content decreased significantly, and the conversion of FF decreased to 81.9 % and 86.6 %, respectively, indicating that excessive Co would not only block the pores or channels of the porous structure but also cause the aggregation of active Co species. In addition, the presence of overly dense active sites on the surface may lead to imbalanced adsorption activation of reactants and desorption of products. As expected, the calcination temperature of catalyst also affects the performance of catalytic transfer hydrogenation (Table 1, Entries 6, 9 and 10). The results proved that the selectivity of FOL increased with the increase in temperature (300–500℃), and began to decline over 700℃. Combined with XRD analysis, it can be concluded that high calcination temperatures will lead to the sintering and agglomeration of active species. Moreover, the catalytic activity of single oxides decreased significantly (Table 1, Entry 11–13), where the catalytic activity of Co3O4 was lower than Al2O3 but higher than MgO. It probably was related to the electronic structure of metal ions, and Al3+ is a typical Lewis acid, which can adsorb oxygen-containing functional groups but whose weak alkalinity was not conducive to the formation of hydrogen species [57]. The Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 sample shows an excellent catalytic activity and selectivity, which is obviously better than those of the same type of catalyst (Table S7). Therefore, the above results revealed that the catalytic activity and selectivity of CoMgAl-LDO in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation can be optimized by adjusting the element proportion and calcination temperature of CoMgAl-LDH precursor. To evaluate the potential of the catalyst for large-scale production of FOL from FF, a scale-up experiment was conducted using 12 mmol of FF as the substrate, which maintained a high catalytic performance (Table 1, Entry 14). 3.3 Effect of reaction parameters Toward our aim of optimized catalytic performance, we further tuned reaction parameters such as reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount, and various hydrogen donor. The effect of the reaction temperature (120–200 ℃) on the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF can be seen in Fig. 6a. the conversion of FF increases from 76.6 % to 99.7 %, while the selectivity of FOL is basically kept above 95 % with increasing temperature from 120 to 160 ℃. Further elevating the reaction temperature from 160 to 200 °C does not boost the conversion of FF. Meanwhile, Fig. 6b shows the effect of the reaction time on catalytic activity and product distribution over Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 was studied at 160℃. As the reaction time raised (2–6 h), the FF conversion increased moderately, merely giving an FF conversion of 99 % even at 6 h, while the FOL yield still stayed above 95 %. Reaction time continues to increase as conversion and selectivity were almost constant. Catalyst amount is also essential parameters for the reaction (Fig. 6c). For the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst, increasing the catalyst amount from 0.05 to 0.10 g led to an obvious improvement in FF conversion from 86.7 % to 99.7 %, there is noticeably little difference in the selectivity towards FOL (95 %). In comparison, when the amount of catalyst was increased to 0.15 g, the FOL selectivity decreased up to 88.5 %, which was caused by the excessively active sites (acid-base sites) promoting the occurrence of aldol condensation reactions (condensation products were detected). Based on the above results, the FOL selectivity of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 was 95.9 % with 99.7 % conversion of FF at optimal reaction conditions (0.10 g catalyst,160 ℃ and 6 h). In the catalytic transfer hydrogenation, the type of hydrogen source can affect the catalytic reaction process. The effects of different alcohols (including primary alcohols and secondary alcohols) on the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL was displayed in Fig. 6d. It can be clearly seen that with the growth of the carbon chain length, the catalytic transfer hydrogenation performance increased. From methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH) to n-propanol (1-PrOH), the conversion of FF increases from 3.20 % to 65.5 %. This phenomenon has also been reported in previous work, where alcohols with specific polarities favor the catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction [58]. More obviously, the secondary alcohol (2-PrOH) showed excellent conversion and selectivity for FF to FOL compared to primary alcohol (1-PrOH), which is attributed to the α-C-H bond energy of secondary alcohols is significantly lower than that of primary alcohols, so it is easy to obtain hydrogen species[59]. the 2-BuOH provided slightly inferior performance than 2-PrOH, which is related to the difference in polarity and mass diffusion of two. 3.4 Substrate scope and recyclability of catalyst The optimized reaction condition was further explored for gram scale catalytic transfer hydrogenation of other biomass carbonyl compounds. As can be seen from Table S8, the conversion of FF, cyclohexanone and cinnamaldehyde over Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 provided good yields (95.6–90.5 %) of the target alcohol products under the optimized reaction condition. However, the conversion and the yield of the target product decreased with the increased carbon chain of tested compound, such as citral. These results clearly displayed the broad applicability of the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst system in the reduction of other biomass aldehydes. In addition to the high catalytic activity, the long-term stability of heterogeneous catalysts is also very important. Thus, the cyclic performance of the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst was further tested under the optimized reaction conditions. Compared with the homogeneous catalytic system, the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst in the experimental catalytic system can be separated from the reaction mixture by the vacuum filter device, washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, dried, and surface organic matter removed by calcination at 500 ℃ in the muffle furnace, then used under the same reaction conditions in the next cycle test. Fig. 7a confirmed that the conversion of FF and the selectivity of FOL remained almost unchanged in the cyclic experiment over Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500. Meanwhile, we conducted a thermal filtration experiment (Fig. 7b). After 4 hours of reaction, the catalyst was filtered and subsequent reactions were observed. The results showed that the conversion rate of FF did not increase and remained unchanged, which also proved that the catalyst has good cycling stability. XRD (Fig. S7), SEM (Fig. S8) and TEM (Fig. S9) were conducted on the fresh catalyst and the catalyst used for 5 times to determine the structural integrity of Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 in the recovery process, which showed that the structure of the catalyst remained basically unchanged before and after the reaction. Therefore, the above results revealed that the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 showed good cycle stability in the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL. 3.5 Probable activation mechanism As mentioned above, the catalytic performance of CoMgAl-LDO is better than the CoMgAl-LDH precursors and other metal oxides catalysts. And the catalytic performance is greatly improved after the introduction of cobalt species compared with MgAl-LDO, which is attributed to the formation of highly dispersed nanoscale Co3O4 in the composite metal oxide catalysts (CoMgAl-LDO), having more active species and moderate acid-base site sites during the calcination of CoMgAl-LDH precursors. Combining these results with the published literature, we proposed a possible mechanism of the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL over CoMgAl-LDO-500 ( Scheme 1). The highly dispersed supported nanoscale Co3O4 can provide moderate Lewis acid-base sites to improve catalytic transfer hydrogenation performance via Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) mechanism. The Lewis acid site (oxidized Co site) and the Lewis basic site (O2-) were mainly responsible for catalytic transfer hydrogenation [60]. First, the Lewis basic site (O2-) adsorb hydrogen species and thus weaken the O-H bond on the 2-PrOH (step 1), and while electron-deficient acid sites (oxidized Co site) can adsorb and activate the CO bond of FF. Subsequently, the Lewis basic site (O2-) adsorb a proton from the alcohol to promote the formation of a six-membered intermediate between the Lewis acid site (oxidized Co site), 2-PrOH, and FF. Then α-H is transferred from the α-C of the 2-PrOH to the CO bond of FF, thus achieving the selective reduction of the CO bond of FF. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of cobalt base ternary compound oxides catalysts (CoMgAl-LDO) with highly dispersed and stable nanoscale Co3O4 are prepared by the calcination of CoMgAl-LDH precursors and applied to the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL using 2-PrOH as a solvent and hydrogen donor. Under optimal reaction conditions, the preferred Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 had FF conversion of exceeded 99 %, and FOL selectivity of more than 95 %, which was higher than the control catalysts. Physicochemical characterization analyses confirmed that Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst had good active species dispersed, large surface area and moderate acid-base site properties. The catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL occurs through the MPV route, in which the basic site (O2- site) promotes the deprotonation of 2-PrOH and the Lewis acid site (oxidized Co site) facilitates the activation adsorption of substrates to form a six-membered intermediate. Furthermore, these catalysts showed excellent cyclic stability after being recycled at least five times and substrate universality. The findings offer a broad potential for the rational design of excellent activity, highly selective, and stable cobalt-based composite oxide catalysts for biomass-related hydrogenation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic furfural (FF) into high value-added furfuryl alcohol (FOL) is a very important biomass improvement process and remains a challenging task. Herein, a series of Co-based composite oxide (CoMgAl-LDO) catalysts with highly dispersed Co3O4-based spinel oxide nanoparticles were synthesized by the topological transformation of Co-based ternary layered hydroxides (CoMgAl-LDH) under calcination conditions and tested for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL using isopropanol (2-PrOH) as hydrogen donor. The CoMgAl-LDO, especially Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO calcinated at 500 °C (Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500) offered the outstanding catalytic performance for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of FF to FOL (99.7 % FF conversion and 95.9 % FOL selectivity), which was attributed to effectively dispersed active sites, abundant acid-base sites and mesoporous structure. Additionally, the Co1.5Mg1.5Al1-LDO-500 catalyst manifested good stability with wider universality to other carbonyl compounds, making the catalytic system extremely economical and practical in various biomass hydrogenation processes.
